reviewText:
Kingdom Wars 2 Battles is a real time strategy game set in fictional world with medieval accents. The game plays as you would expect a game of this genre to but a few added mechanics and an online multiplayer mode keep things fresh for players. While this isn’t a genre I am very familiar with I did find the game enjoyable, it can easily be played for hours as you spend time focusing on micromanaging your units. The game offers single player and campaign modes if you just want to enjoy it on your own.

The story in the campaign mode focuses on the race of humans mainly fighting against orcs. Humanity is on the run from their aggressors, periodically making valiant stands to secure their survival. Each step of the story is told via cutscenes with voice over explaining the battle and what takes place before and after it. An interesting plot point in the game is the presence of zombies -the result of cannibalism, no doubt committed by desperate war-refugees. The story itself is currently one episode with five chapters.

The game’s mechanics work very well, while I mainly played the campaign mode I also found that the multiplayer mode was a fun option for those wanting to increase the game’s replay value. The game also has a great single player mode where you can play your own adventure or a survival mode. All units in the game are under your control, even down to farm animals. The worker class mines, farms and builds while fighters help protect and progress. Both classes are important to the game as is resource and time management. The game works best with a keyboard and mouse requiring both to control the camera and click on areas of interest. Each unit and building have a large variety of actions and options available to players that help to customize gameplay experiences.

The graphics in the game are simple, and even a bit dated. Character models are basic and not overly-detailed and I found some of the buildings hard to tell apart visually. Maps are also standard, nothing is bad but nothing really stands out much either. I found it a little hard to tell the tiny units on the map apart as their uniform colors were often the same. The audio in the game is fine, the characters talk when you click on them and there is some voice over as well. The music is fitting, but not memorable.

I found the game to be a good way for novices such as myself to learn about real time strategy, or fans who haven’t played a game in the genre for a while. Kingdom Wars 2 Battles offers a lot of options and customizing choices to tailor gameplay to each person as well as three different races to choose from; humans, orcs and elves. No matter what option you pick the game will be fun and challenging, plus there are trading card and achievements to keep a person coming back for more. With a hands-on development team regularly updating the game, this title is a great addition to any library.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To cut straight to the chase, this is my favorite strategy game to date, and that is not due to lack of variety. I have played a large amount of RTS such as Sins of a Solar Empire, Age of Empires, Total War, and Star Wars: Empire at War, and various others.

Yet none of the above gave quite the satisfaction that Kingdom Wars 2: Battles does, and that is not due to cheap gimmicks or repetitive game play.

Just to give a brief bullet point list of some of the features that I find quite enjoyable:

- Faction Diversity
- Unit Specialization
- Fire, lots of fire
- Size of maps allow many forms of combat
- Zombies
- Unit Diversity

Now, to go over each piece individually.

Faction Diversity
Each faction quite simply plays very different from each other, and while there is a slight bit of overlap, as there is in every RTS, each have their own tricks and techniques to master. For example, the Orc Faction has the highest number of soldiers per unit as well as the ability to mass produce weak units such as goblins, which can win wars of attrition if you play your cards right. On the other hand, the Human Faction has some of the tankiest units in the game but is more of a balance between Elves and Orcs than anything else. Other than their durability, their units do not stick out too much, but it is quite pivotal if you are able to compound on such. Finally, the Elves, have the lowest soldiers per unit, but also have the highest quality of units, which allow them to defeat superior numbers more often than not. Despite all of this though, each faction has balanced counters and maneuvers to use against each other, with no one strategy being undefeatable. For each move, there is a counter move, for every counter move there is another counter. In essence, balance is maintained for the most part, with no one Faction getting too far ahead of the others. Each can be phenomenal in the right player’s hands.

Unit Specialization
Quite simple really, but each unit has 'levels' that they achieve when they have gained enough experience from combat. This in turn, allows you to distribute stats for that unit as you see fit, meaning that a full blown army can be as unique as you deem fit. It could be as simple as maxing out the defensive stats, or going for full out mobility... Yet each is viable in different situations, with no one configuration being the end all be all. Diversity is the word of the game.

Fire
This one is much simpler than the previous item, in that it is quite self-explanatory. Archers and siege equipment can make use of fire to damage buildings, do extra damage to units, or even light the battle field itself on fire. In short, just as in real life, fire is one hell of a weapon.

Map Size
There are four castle plots, one taken by each player unless there are less than four of course. Each one is in a corner of the map, with defensible positions dotted all over the place, including bridges, ruins, quarries, and npc forts. The time it takes to travel across the map isn't too long, but just long enough to make you think before emptying your garrison. Caught without an army at home, you will suffer the consequences.

Zombies
A relatively new addition, these buggers form up large hordes outside your castle and in essence prolong the game unless you can circumvent them. You used to be able to direct them against your opponents with clever sacrifice of units, but they are more a field threat these days. Every unit that dies and is not looted... Well... Expect to see them again. Not only does this add some threat to the general map to consider when moving about, but it also being key to use scouts to avoid them or funnel enemies towards them. While they are destructible, they can still wreak quite a bit of havoc before being put down.

Unit Diversity
Each Faction has some basic units similar to another, but even then, each have their own defining characteristics. Take spearmen for example, orcs have Impalers, elves Sentries, and humans Halberdiers. The Halberdiers lack special abilities, but have higher base stats and are able to cut down monsters and Calvary quite efficiently. Impalers on the other hand are slow and lower damage, as well as health, but have an AoE ability that can one shot a large charging Calvary force, as well as stun them, not to mention it works decently against other infantry as well. Sentries on the other hand have a stun ability, which allows them to combat Calvary and monsters while taking little damage. What we have here, are three different units designed for the same task, yet go about doing it in completely different ways. Nor are they only type to have such differences.


In short, KW2 is a great RTS that gets you in the action, gives you the tools to create the army you always dreamed of commanding, and to proceed however you want. Want stealth based combat? Elves have plenty of that, and the Orc's Goblins can do such as well. Want to take a tanky approach? All three have their own methods, such as Slayers, Knights, and Grandmasters. Archers? Most definitely. Another interesting thing, is the siege equipment... But I might as well not spoil it for those who have not played yet, but suffice to say, they can be used in a variety of situations.

Don't believe me on half of what I said? Try it for yourself, and you are sure to find something you enjoy here.

Sincerely, The Goblin King

Early Access Review

Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is an incredibly interesting concept in todays view of rts strategy games. It takes mechanics from all over, with resource nodes from games like age of empires or empire earth; huge scale combat from the total war games including the batallions of x amount of units per squad. It's so nostalgic and at the same time thrilling to play a game like this. As much as I'd like to praise it up to the stars and call it the new messiah, I can't do that fairly. So let's look at some of the negatives I've noticed during gameplay.
- Archers: These guys are useful, but good god can they not aim at times. If you stick them on a wall, sure they'll aim as well as they can, but when you have about 3 orcish marauders (orc archers) left in a squad firing at your 5 squads on a wall, and killing them like flies while hundreds of arrows rain down upon the orcish invaders, and not a single one is hitting them, it's a little bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥. It's not even a case of them having godly luck by dodging, the archers just don't aim at them. They aim a bit to the left, or a bit to the right, and every single arrow aims in that spot instead of where the enemy is actually standing! It's infuriating! The siege is the same too, missing countless shots and wasting ammunition to try and flatten the ground next to the invader. AGH!
- Terrain: This is a little bugbear of mine, but it still counts in this. On some maps you play singleplayer, I've found that if I try to play humans, and have stone walls defending the core of my city, I can't place anyone on the outer layer. By outer layer I mean the humans have a kind of bastion style design. If intruders break through the outer walls, they have to break through the inner gates. But the inner gates are broken into two parts. I won't fully explain it since I'd sound like an utter ♥♥♥♥♥ trying to explain something I don't know about, but look it up. I'm sure there are a few images flying around of the human castles by now.
- Balance: As of the current release of the game, I've found that the elves are insanely overpowered. Now, in a lot of games I've played over the years, elves can be quite dangerous, but if you try enough, they'll fall over flat on their pretty little faces. In this game? Good god. They're the same as all others, don't get me wrong. Push enough and they'll still die. But in terms of resources, they will outlast you. How? They get a building called a symbiosis tree, which allows them to CREATE resources. Yup, I really mean that. They can create gold mines, stone mines, even more berries if they so fancy. This means they can keep pumping out entire armies of powerful troops, while you're scrounging around the map desperately trying to find some gold for another squad of knights.
- Walls: Useful, correct? well, not when the wall is blocking all your arrows trying to murder a single zombie battering down your damn gate, and you can't open that gate because the zombie is hitting it. Infuriating, especially as an orc, since you only get one exit out of your plateau. Truly infuriating. It's made even worse when you watch your archers arrows hit thin air way above the barricades and the enemy on the other side is perfectly safe. Worst bugbear ever.

Now, I know that a lot of these problems should be solved during the next couple updates, and admittedly they'll take a while. I'm an impatient person so I want them as soon as possible, so I can enjoy this game even more. But on the whole, for the feel this game gives you when you play this, it's totally worth it in my opinion. Especially for the price right now. £10.99? I'd pay £20 for this game, just because it's brilliant, and brings back the main thing I love in games like this; strategic options. Rush them, or defend. It's your choice.

Kingdom Wars 2: Battles:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A kingdom without a king is a recipe for war! Three races are engaged in this devastating conflict and trying to survive. Who is going to have the upper hand? Would it be the Orcs, possibly the Elves or it just might be the Humans?!

Kingdom War 2: Battles is an RTS game which offers several modes of play. In the campaign mode, you will be playing four episodes at this stage (the fifth episode is coming soon), you will be treated with very good cinematics as well as an in-depth story line. This episode with be all about the last stronghold for the human race, the city of “Dagbor.” You will be playing the Humans and then the Orcs. During the gameplay, you will have to achieve all tasks before entering a battle. Essentially, it is like a very good tutorial. You will learn how to gather resources, create buildings and units.

The single player mode is realistically a skirmish; choose your race and up to three others players (AI) to fight against. In the survival mode, you will be fighting against waves of zombies.

There is quite a lot of content here. There is a technology tree for the 3 races and you can unlock upgrade with different resources. If you are missing some, head up to the trade centre and buy what you need from another user. By clicking on the social icon, you will be able to see who is online, become a friend with whoever you want, challenge or engage in a co-op game.

Strategic cards can be crafted and used in a multiplayer game. Select a combination of cards to have the edge against your opponent but be aware, they might have a better combination than you.

The gameplay is good, as are the graphics, although I did experience a couple of flicking screen effects here and there.

The controls are easy to master and follow the trend of this type of game. The only negative here is that I had to click several times to the same points for my units to acknowledge my command, and this can be frustrating.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Good graphics
-	Good story and cinematics
-	3 races to play with each their specific tech tree
-	Achievements and Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Controls could be more responsive

I really like RTS and Kingdom War 2: Battles show great potential.

7.5/10

reviewText:
If you’re looking for a game that genuinely feels increasingly rewarding the longer than you play it then I urge you to try Reverie World Studios Kingdom Wars 2: Battles that has been recently released out of Steam Early Access.

Although the game was bundled twice during its Early Access period, meaning many of you may already own the game and therefore have an even greater reason to play it now, the game is definitely worth its asking price especially for those of you who have the time and the energy to make the effort to playing this through to completion. Although I’ve spent four hours playing the game I can already foreshadow that this is the type of game that you could easily sink hundreds of hours in. There are five full campaigns and that’s without even considering the multiplayer. As of writing there are well over one hundred players playing and the in game chat system was vibrant and active so finding a match shouldn’t be a problem for some time.

One of the best things about the game is that there are three playable races. However, unlike a number of other games where each race feels very much alike even though units and buildings may be given different names the play styles of each race feel very different from one another. If not for the graphics then at times you would have a hard time believing that you were playing the same game which is a real boon for a genre where variety can be an important selling point. Another strength of the three race system in this game is that – at least in my experience – none of the races play over or underpowered when compared to the other. Certainly there may be a race that plays to your own individual strengths or against your weaknesses but it is a game where putting in the time to learn to master one or more will give you an advantage in the multiplayer.

There are some weaknesses to the game. My biggest one would be the graphics. The UI, because of the graphics, needs a fair amount of work but I’m not entirely certain as to how I would go to polish it but I do know that it needs work from its present state. At times the screen can be too busy and I found it difficult in these times to know which units – peasants – weren’t being busy. This is especially apparent on the tutorial level where there are just so many different units that bombard you that you can lose track of what is happening all too quickly. I know that I wasn’t the first player to lose at the tutorial level and have this complaint. There are also some bugs that continue to remain in the game. However, to be very fair to the developers, they’ve been great and are removing them from the game at a rapid pace and this has been the case throughout the entirety of the development process.

However, the tutorial level – even if you include the fact that there is a little bit too much going on – is one of the better ones that I’ve played. It’s a welcome introduction to the challenge that you will be experiencing throughout the game. This isn’t a walk in the park regardless of the level of difficulty that you play on and that is as it should be. Some players may well be frustrated at just how tough the challenge can be but if you’re wanting an engaging and challenging game in this genre then you’ve found it.

My favorite aspect of the game is the fantastic skirmish gameplay. This is genuinely the type of game that I would recommend to those who loved the original Warcraft games as well as those of you who play Rise of Nations and other similar games. You’ll be surprised at just how much depth there is to your city/base building while also at the same time how strategically you must be in designing the type of armies that will enable you to be successful. Players of both types of games will be at a distinct advantage as you utilize a combination of the skills throughout the campaign and multiplayer modes.

There is a ton to like about Kingdom Wars 2: Battles. There is potential for the title to become even better. The devs have been great and if they continue working on the title then it could become a classic. If you already own the game thanks to the Damnation Bundle from Bundle Stars or the Be Mine 21 bundle from Groupees then get on board and play it. If not and you’re a fan of the game then you really owe it to yourself to check it out if not right away then when it goes on sale.

Kingdom Wars 2: Battles Review
Kingdom Wars 2: Battles (which I will refer to as KW2B in this review) is a bold approach to RTS strategic simulation games that focuses on the building and destroying of massive medieval citadels. The battles are intense and the strategy is unlike most other simulations out there so most players can expect a challenging experience unlike any they have faced before. That is, unless you happened to play the original Kingdom Wars. What gives this series its unique flavor is Reverie World Studios, INC's strong focus on siege warfare, making it unlike anything else being developed.

Players will naturally need to gather resources, build structures, research technologies, and train armies just like in most other RTS sims of this nature. However, the economy and techs have all been streamlined so the player doesn't have to micro-manage their progression and can devote most of their attention to the battles themselves. Currently there are three races to choose from: Humans, Elves, and Orcs. Each race has its own unique units, structures and styles. Since the game is still Early Access, its possible that more will be added later but I cannot say for certain.

Players can choose between single-player story mode played out in episodes, skirmish mode, and Multiplayer mode. There is only one episode available now but current plans include five in total and these additional episodes will be released as Free DLC's. Other features in the works include a crafting system based on rewards earned during battles for a variety of advancements, an intricate card system used for powerful bonuses during games, a trading market where players can trade crafting items with other players, and a guild system that will allow players to create or join a battle clan for shared strength. At this time, some of these things are still in development so its not easy to elaborate on them, but they sound pretty cool.

The graphics are very rich but older systems struggle to keep up on moderately high settings so this may change in order to accommodate more players, especially for Multiplayer PvP. There is an in-game chat system so players can communicate during gameplay without the hassles of using the Steam overlay. A level editor is included for the mod community can get a jumpstart on their own creations. The sound effects are a bit troublesome currently and being sorted out. Nothing new for an Alpha version though. Also, there are still a number of bugs scattered about so don't be alarmed. This is typical of an Early Access game and the devs welcome any information on them so they can work to correct the problems. Still, the game is very stable and entertaining. Being part of the Early Access phase gives players the opportunity to help shape the future of KW2B and help the developers build the best game possible. However, if you're one of those gamers who has little patience or prefers only finished/polished projects, then i suggest holding off a while longer. Unhappy gamers do nothing to help the community, the developers, or the game.

The Good:
=======+  Solid graphics and detailed artwork
+  Three fully unique races
+  Various player modes for added replay value
+  Crafting and Card systems for player bonuses
+  Fully rotating camera with smooth controls
+  In-game chat system
+  Steam Achievements & Trading Cards
+  Level Editor included for the Workshop
+  Active & friendly game devs
+  Free DLC's
+  More cool features being added

The Bad:
======-  Still has a lot of bugs to be worked out (typical for Early Access)
-  Audio is a mess right now
-  User Interface and layout still needs some work
-  Many features and elements are missing (still under development)
-  Graphics are a strain on older systems

Final Thoughts:
===========KW2B has all the promise of a great game and I have no doubt the developers will see this game all the way through to a polished gem. Siege warfare is often a neglected aspect of RTS strategy sims and its rarely done properly so this game offers a fresh experience for most players. Strategy players will definitely want to grab a copy and strap in for battle. This game isn't the best choice for impatient people or those who expect to have a smooth and complete experience since its still Early Access Alpha though.

When I stumbled upon Kingdom Wars 2: Battles, my friend and I were looking at Rome 2: Total War and whether I should buy it. One look at this though, mostly because of the price difference, made me have a look at this game instead. And I don't regret it one bit!

The first thing I noticed that made this game a winner was the world chat. Basically, no matter if you are in the main menu, campaign, singleplayer or multiplayer, you are always able to speak with everyone else currently online. This is HUGE in my honest opinion, and it makes it way easier to get in touch with the devs too, since they are often in the world chat.

Features:
This game has crafting as a part of its learning process. This means you are not spammed with too many decisions in your first few games, and if you take the time to craft exactly what you want, the new buildings or units you can get in your next games won't feel so alien.

You also get to craft cards, which when activated gives you a small boost in your current games. These cards must be recrafted every 4 times you use them, but you get the resources to do so every game, so it's not such a big deal.

Guilds also exist in these games, with ratings for all the guilds, so you can fight together with your friends in rated games for ultimate glory.

Gameplay:
This game has everything I'm looking for in an RTS: Fast-paced combat, a managable start (unlike Age of Empires or Starcraft, where you have to sit with your hotkey fingers ready for the first second), castle defending and attacking, and a massive zombie feature that lets you suicide bomb your army outside your enemies' base and turn them into zombies.

This game has benefits for focusing on defense as well as offense, and if you can defend yourself against the first wave without taking too much losses, your units will level up from it, becoming stronger and stronger. This is when you can launch a counter-assault, sending your elite units on your opponent and decimating their defenses.

You start with your very own fortress with walls, and you can build additional sets of walls and upgrade them to stone structures with enough resources. You can put archer units on the walls, and also build towers or anti-siege equipment to make it harder to penetrate your defenses. Boiling oil pots and trebuchets give you the ability to kill siege units that are below your gates and far away, and your archers can perform volleys of arrows that decimate those who are stranding still too close to your walls.

There are some issues with the game still, like the sound is a bit loud some places (so you might want to turn down your volume once ingame), and your units not moving when you tell them to sometimes. All of this is being worked at however, so I'm not worried. It's still the most fun RTS I've played in forever.

You should buy this if you enjoy massive army combat, units that can level up in many different ways, and zombies. Lots and lots of zombies.

Early Access Review

Alright, now that i've had some actual time to see the game, and the work going into it, I can make a formal opinion on the game itself... and i'm conflicted.
Kingdom Wars 2 has all the makings of a classic, aswell as a few things that make it definately stand out, some things seem like poor choices... i don't know why there's a progression system in an RTS, or why its next to impossible to get any of the high level crafting objects, but those are just nitpicks, so lets tear into the game as a whole shall we? I'll be judging it as if it was a finished project so anything that ends up being ironed out when you read this may no longer be applicable.

The game features the standard 3 factions, a faction with expensive troops, a faction with tankish troops, and a faction with cheap troops, however each faction works in very unique ways such as how they gather their resources and how they build their armies, which is a neat thing to see in an RTS.

As far as combat goes, there's no collision between units, so its impossible to hold off a group of enemies without a closed gate. resource management seems fine, though managing all your peasants and keeping track of your troops can be difficult. Kingdom wars 2 is also the first RTS I've seen to feature zombification as a mechanic, and its more or less clunky, it really just makes sieges more of a hassle and slows the game down, but it has its high moments, there's a lot tension when a massive army of your troops or an enemy's army has been defeated near something important, and you need to clear the area of corpses before either: your enemy arrives again or the sun sets.

The strategy side of this game seems fairly weak, though it could just be that the game is new and there isn't a community cooking up the best ways to win at everything, but it seems to me that all it takes at the moment is a massive horde of your weakest non-peasant troops and a couple battering rams, since again, you don't have to kill your enemies, you just have to touch their flag for 30 seconds or something.

Then there's presentation, The game seems riddled with glitchs, and is poorly optimized, expect constant lag in both single player and pvp. Also, there seems to be a bug that causes all gui's relating to buildings and units to simply not appear, meaning it can suddenly become impossible for you to build any more troops or buildings.

In conclusion, yes the game is in early access, but that still doesn't mean it isn't broken, I'd normally say thats enough for me to not reccomend it, however updates are fairly often, and the devs do seem very invested in the community around this game, so I'm actually going to go ahead and recommend you support them... for now.

This is a game that at face value looks rough around the edges. Being an RTS/Stategy/Simulation-ish game, it fills a very niche market, one which I always struggle to find the right game for me, that satisfies my every need - decent castle building, solid warfare, economy / resource gathering and units gaining veternacy with progression, and I can gladly say that this game fulfills my every need.

One of my favourite features - zombie survival in an RTS! You have a castle like a normal game but you're tasked with surviving wave after wave and this can be done cooperatively! This is just a taste of what the game offers and I have barely scratched the surface my self, but with such helpful and ACTIVE dev team members in game chat (which is visible throughout all games and menus) I felt compelled to write my first review of a game in a long time.

Buy it, support the produces and watch this fantastic game grow - there's a lot to offer and the team have an amazing philosophy, something we cannot say for most modern games these days.

Summary
Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a medieval styled strategy game with a affection to card games and massive battles. You get the chance to control your own empire of orcs, elves or humans in a war shattered world with with their very own play style and build-up system.
Playing each single race feels totally different to the other ones and the player needs to choose wisely between them and their belonging cards to match their own type of tactics.

Less micromanagement due to squads of units
Possibility to fight relatively huge battles
Based on old school games like Starcraft, Warcraft and AoE
Fast update and development progress
Stable gameplay despite being early access
Level-up system based on cards

Con'sGraphics are still partly early stage
Rather bad pathfinding (soon to change)
Battles seem pretty buggy at this point - Most arrows can't hit their target properly and units behave pretty dumb at some points

My own Conclusion
When playing this game for the first time I felt like being reminded of my first gaming adventures with those good old strategy classics like Age of Empires or Warcraft 2 - this game got a big potential of becoming the next attempt to revive the dying art of building strategy games. Also the first few campaign missions gave a nice introduction to the future of this game.

There is indeed only one thing I can really complain about at this very moment: The game is still unfinished - that needs to be changed ASAP.

reviewText:
This is a fairly fresh approach to the RTS genre, it throws in a few things which just make the game so much more enjoyable.
It seems to take a few ideas from games such as AOE III, and by that I mean you can use cards during the game for extra resources, a few troops etc, only difference being you will have to craft these cards.
You also have to play the game through a bit before fully unlocking all units and benefits within, as you receive materials for finishing matches which can then be used to craft new techs.

Gameplay is pretty standard RTS, with a few suprises which keep you on your feet. Your base will fortify itself by upgrades, and (this is one of my favourite things in an RTS) you can position your archers on your walls to defend from invaders. There are scattered benefits around the map, such as extra resource deposits for your workers to mine, gold carts (defended by packs of wolves usually), and small forts (defended by bandits) which are good for strategic positions.
The main thing I love about this game, which had me and a friend thoroughly entertained, was that your (and your allies/enemies) troops don't stay dead.. They will rise again as zombies, and at night are even worse to deal with. Essentially, even if you win a fight against your opposition, you'd best get your troops far away from there, or at least hope to god that that fight didn't take place near your base. The zombies swarm, you fight them off with troops and lose more, they gain more zombies, it becomes a losing battle fast.

There is also a survival gamemode, in which you (and allies) defend your bases against zombie hordes. It seems like a normal gamemode, except instead of fortresses they have cemeteries spawning zombies at increasing rates every round. It becomes hilarious and terrifying the longer the game goes on.

Pros:
-Fun gameplay
-Great multiplayer
-Fun Gamemodes
-Interesting advancement with crafting techs for new units
-Collecting materials makes tryharding those slow AI matches worthwhile

Cons:
-Not completelty optimised if your PC isn't fantastic, can get very framey at times (the worst during the survival gamemode)
-Limited to 3 different teams (races)
-A slight lack of unit variety on each time
-Limited amount of maps to play on as opposed to randomly generated maps on other RTS'

Overall, the only cons of the game are things which can be improved over time and in further development/expansions, and I hear a new expansion (free, might I add) is coming in May. If you're questioning whether the game is worth its price, I highly recommend it. You'll get many hours out of the base game alone, plus with the free upcoming expansion I'm sure there's many more hours to pour into it.

Tl;dr - RTS game with many unique ideas/gamemodes, great fun and guaranteed to have a good time.

Early Access Review

This is an early access review so take it with a grain of salt.

I really enjoy this game for a multitude of reasons.

One of those reasons is the addition of zombies as a game mechanic in the game. It is something that isnt done in the RTS genre, and it really opens up different avenues of strategy in taking down the enemy base. Another consequence of this game mechanic is that it forces you to make sure that you have enough troops when exploring or else you will be overrun by your -former- soldiers as they die off.

There are many other reasons why this game is great but they are commonplace in the RTS genre.

Now, for the reasons why this game sometimes annoys me.

- You need to unlock the tech tree for each race individually using items and other things found during your campaigns. This makes it feel grindey just trying to get the tech.

- There are a multitude of bugs such as units getting stuck and units not following orders

- Siege rams are way too op right now. I shouldnt be able to take down three gates with a single ram against a fully defended castle


However, despite these cons (most of which can be fixed by either game balancing or bug fixing) this game is a definite buy.

It is quite similar to Battle For Middle-Earth II, except this game has more realistic battle mechanics, especially archers - in this game, they are not OP, and you have no chance of succeeding in any battle with archers only. They do make a very useful support though - so, just like they did in actual historical warfare.

One of the things that make this game stand out so much, is how amazingly detailed, scrupulous, and complex its siege mechanics are - there are ladders, belfrys, trebuchets, battering rams, mantlets, and many more contraptions and techniques in which you can break down your enemy´s walls, breach them, or bypass them. On the other hand, you can pour hot oil down from your battlements, or throw rocks, you can install catapults on them to help you defend, build high towers where you can place your archers for a tactical advantage, and more!

I´m not going to lie - my first impression was a mix of confusion, disorientation, and frustration. This game is complex, hard to understand at first, and certainly can pose an intellectual and strategic challenge. And I love that. Once you understand how economy works in this game, and get used to controlling your troops, this game will show itself in its entire greatness.

There are zombies, dragons, mages, mighty heroes, as well as countless other, less fantasy-esque units and foes. You can build a vast army, that will storm your enemy´s city and lay waste to it, or you can level up a few heroes, supported by a mage, who wreaks havoc with his powerful spells, and try taking the entire city on with just a few mighty individuals, much like in Battle For Middle-Earth.

This game is absolutely worth its cost, not just the money, the time spent playing, the initial confusion, the effort you put in learning to play this game, all of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers.

Kingdom Wars 2: Battles review

Graphics

KW2 has some very impressive graphics that sadly require one meaty boss of a computer to even go on medium settings. However the game's still beautiful even on the very low settings. So all that it would take is some improved optimisation to make the game more playable. I can play 99% of games on maxed out setting, but this game only runs on 25fps, so that will make KW2 to lose a few points. Apart from poor optimisation, the game is a masterpiece, no questions needed. Although you don't always get to just stare at this work ofart for too long as there is always action to be seen.

Gameplay
This game is like the Total War series (the good games of the series), Clash of Clans (for a giant amount of things you can build) and Company of Hereos had a marvelous baby. You can build tons of different thigns (each race has different buildings), there's a campaign mode, a gigantic variety of classes (every race has different classes), different ways to gather up resources (races have different ways to get them), different advantages and disadvantages throughout the races, multiplayer, singleplayer, and so, so much more content. So to tum this topic up, if you like a lot of content in a game, this is will fullfil your expectation even more than you could wish for it to.

Races
There's currently 3 classes. Humans, Orcs and Elves. Humans are the most basic class (and the most boring)... why would you want to choose them? Well, maybe if you're new to the game you will choose them. The second class is Orcs, just as you might think, some really cool guys who are violent, much like the Vikings but in a beast form. Last but not least, there's Elves! These guys might look boring, but if you play as them, you'll know how powerful they are. They can technically have never ending resources with only a bit of work. Also, they have unicorns... fantastic game 10/10 - Wolff. So hopefully in the future we'll either see some workshop content or more races such as... uh... something.

Building
Think of Sid Meiers' game series and Rome: Total War 2s' mechanics inside of one masterpiece. As already mentioned from my description, this game has an excellent style of building. There's tons of buildings, upgrades, walls, and a bunch more items that you, the player, can use to either an advantage or disadvantage. As you can build, the opposition can do the same. And if you can attack, you can destory. Does that give you a hint? Yes, you can invade others settlement and completely destroy it. After that, you can do an even more horrible thing and loot the townsfolk that you have just slaughtered for different loot.

Pros vs Cons
Pros:
In depth building
Graphics are jaw-dropping
Very fun
Unlike other games
Tech tree's
Singleplayer
Multiplayer
Campaign mode
Races
Classes
Upgrades

Cons:
Very poor optimization
Buggy (this should be an excpetion since it's Early Acces, but there's too much bugs)

Overall score
8/10 - Even with lots of bugs and bad optimization, it's still an excellent game. Worth picking up once on discount, even if you're a non-gamer!

reviewText:
The developers have added a lot of content since when I first bought it, which was awhile ago. As a player of RTS style games for many years now, I can safely say this is one of the greatest indie RTS games I have played. In fact it is a solid RTS, for the price, and I haven't really seen anything that was comparable.

It features:
Progressive Gameplay; I.e. upgrade talent tree that is outside of the actual battles. You gain loot and such, then spend it to gain benefits, such as a knight, or spearman, buildings, etc.

Common RTS elements and uncommon RTS elements, all that are good. Base building, troops, management of resources. Uncommon includes choosing to grow chickens vs pigs, to send a cart or not, where to build a farm, how to use the resources. Do I use the wood for this or that, what do I use the stone for, the gold for, do I use food for peasants or soldiers?

Each match (this was awhile ago, sorry if review is outdated), plays out with a strong tactical gameplay set AND elements normally limited to turn based games. The maps are fair sized, and there are plenty of objects to go for. Want more gold, get a cart, some peasants, and send them out to mine. You may need to station soldiers nearby to protect them from enemies, including the undead.

Speaking of the fallen, things that die have a tendency to, well, come back to kill you. If things are left unlooted, which must be done by peasants, they will come back and be an annoyance. At first this seems trivial, but can be abused to cause injury to your foes. Raid the neutral camp near your enemy's base early into the game with a medium sized force. This way if your troops succeed, a large dead force will strike at their peasants and fort, and if not hopefully many die, and the same result may happen to your foe.

Neutral camps, the enemies vary, usually protect resources that you need in order to survive and expand, and are worth looking into.

The game is somewhat complex, and has bugs, but is definitely worth the investment.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a RTS with an interesting crafting system entwined with classic RTS gameplay and a great story.

The Story:

The story in Kingdom Wars 2: Battles is a great one pitting Humans against Orcs from the get go. The cutscenes are narrated with quality dialog making it feel like you are there commanding the forces and overcoming the challenges. The setting is somewhat different from other RTS games due to Human forces being on the defensive from the invading Orcs. To avoid any large spoilers I won’t go further into detail  but it is a story that will keep you playing.

Gameplay:

Now gameplay is where any RTS shines the most. There are several ways to overcome a challenge like instead of scaling walls with ladders why not smash it in with a battering ram! There are plenty of units to complement anyone's play style. The crafting aspects enhance the gameplay further giving you an edge over your enemy.In today’s internet age no game is complete without multiplayer. Kingdom Wars 2: Battles has your multiplayer RTS needs covered with intense PVP or co-operative play. There are also free content updates no season pass to get the latest chapter or added content! So many great things but every game has some bad mixed in with the good. The tutorial could have been longer and more in depth on certain mechanics. Resource management takes some getting used to. Overall it was still one of the best gameplay experiences in months for me

Bugs and Glitches:

No game is perfect bugs and glitches happen they are fixed Kingdom Wars 2: Battles has only a few annoying bugs. One cutscene bugged forcing me to close the game.There are some visual bugs also like textures stretching in weird ways. The bugs and glitches are mostly minor and don’t lessen the gameplay or story quality at all.

Pros and Cons:

Pros:
Great story
Crafting system
Card battles
Intense battles
Multiplayer
Multiple unit types
Voiced dialog
Help menu
Multiple ways to overcome a challenge
Free expansion pack

Cons:
Small visual bugs
Tutorial could be better
Resource management can be tough for those new to the game

reviewText:
Well, i don't like to write bad reviews, but new people should be advised about this game.

Regarding the Pros and Cons:

Pros:
+ Zombie addiction: i think it's the most beautiful thing in a rts game: with big battle you can turn the field in a bloody horde of zombie that will go to attack your base and everything they will meet, you need to burn them or send your civilians for cleaning the bodies or the zombies will spawn every time.
+ I like the 3 factions: they are different with their pros and cons, they made them very good.
+ The economy system is good: you have to collect wood, gold, food and stone.  But you need to choose carefully your strategies, because gold and stone are limited if you don't build the other things for collect the resources ( each factions have their way to do it).
+ Battles are great and funny, you can build from soldiers to orcs, monsters and everything else (it depends from your faction).
+ They are working hard for improving the game.

Cons:
- Lag: there is a lot of lag when you select your units,when you play with more than 1 AI, definitively it's unplayable. This is the most bad thing in the game, it ruins a lot your game's exprience.
- The map variety is not so good. All the map are similar, and they need a re-balance for the resources nodes.
- Ai: Despite the last improvements, it still needs a lot of work.
- Even though you play single player, you need a connection for using your techs that you will aquire after winning some battles. For that you may incur in the lag on single player when you move units etc.
- You can't mod anything and with editor you can make only scenarios. They enabled the workshop, but there is only one file.

Conclusion: At this price i don't suggest to buy it, it's not worth (in my side it costs 27,99 euro). Devs are trying hard for improving the game, but they are a small company, so it needs long time before having a 'full and complete game'.
I will update my review, but for now it's negative.

reviewText:
I did not enjoy my brief experience in the game.

I had thought this would be a nice construction based RTS, which I like quite a bit. And it's true, the construction is a highlight of the game. Watching the walls go up, expanding the walls, and reinforcing the walls with defences is very fun. That was the only fun part of the game I could find.

The many bugs made the game frustriating. the graphics are painful and the saturation is driven up to hide it. The UI is a mess. Units aquire skill points, which means you have to go to each group of units and distribute their skillpoints one at a time. The AI is bad, and the neutral outposts seem to be pointless.

The Combat AI really made it unplayable though. Telling melee units to attack a unit, they will attack exactly that unit, and only that unit, even if they need to walk behind 3 lines of enemies to get to him. You can't even form a wall to prevent the enemy from walking past you, not that the AI would anyway. Just stick with archers who at least autoattack. Worse, there are no formations or advanced orders. The best you can do is tell your units to form a line facing one direction or another, making combat tactics paper thin.

I expected fewer poor design choices and bugs from an indy studio.

Pros:
-Cool wall construction and upgrade machanics ++
-Old school style resource collection +
-Old school style unit design+

Cons:
-Bad map AI, Worse combat AI -
-Blinding graphics and saturation --
-Frustrating glitches -
-Lack of formations or complex strategy ---
-Old school unit design -

Verdict:
Don't believe the fanboyst. Unless you really want to built walls stay away, even at 50% off.

reviewText:
I'm not going to complain about the graphics; they are more or less what is advertised in the screenshots. Dated, yes, but marginally improved over KW 1.

I initially gave this game a thumbs-down, citing it was unpolished, buggy, and generally a mess. Matches were unwinnable, in a number of ways. Content was limited, maps were few in number, and the primary game mode was a half-finished survival style of game.

I'm happy to say the game has been significantly improved since then. Yes, it's still a bit ugly (perhaps more specifically dated looking), has a clunky UI, and seems to ignore mouseclicks every so often. What it does do is provide an enjoyable gaming experience, within the very specific realm of a survival style siege defense game. The competitive multiplayer I haven't played much, but judging by comments, continues to go in the sort of balance circles we've become familiar with in recent years. (Rock OP, Paper is fine. -Scissors.)

I don't consider the patches and fixes they've released for free to be a glorious gift, full of exciting new content, but they are still patches and fixes, a sign that the developers are committed to continuously improving and expanding the game.

Kingdom Wars: Battles has always been a game for a specific nice sort of player, looking for a particular experience. However, it's gone from being a lousy way to fill that niche to being a satisfying and enjoyable one.
